column2: the province dates from states of the Holy Roman Empire and takes its name from the nearby German city of Geldern.  According to the Wichard saga
column3: the city was named by the Lords of Pont who fought and killed a dragon in 878 AD. They named the town they founded after the death rattle of the dragon: "Gelre!"The County of Guelders arose out of the Frankish pagus Hamaland in the 11th century around castles near Roermond and Geldern. The counts of Gelre acquired the Betuwe and Veluwe regions and
column5: the County of Zutphen. Thus the counts of Guelders laid the foundation for a territorial power that
column9: was to play an important role in the later Middle Ages. The geographical position of their territory dictated the external policy of the counts during the following centuries; they were committed to the interests of the Holy Roman Empire and to expansion south and west.  Sir Ulrich von Lichtenstein from Gelderland brought fame to the region in the 1370s by winning the world championship in fencing in London.

column1: Further enlarged by the acquisition of the imperial city of Nijmegen in the 13th century
column2: the countship was raised to a duchy in 1339 by the Holy Roman Emperor
column4: the duchy was ruled from Jülich and by the counts of Egmond and Cleves. The duchy resisted Burgundian domination
column6: Duke of Jülich-Cleves-Berg was forced to cede it to Charles V in 1543
column7: after which it formed part of the Burgundian-Habsburg hereditary lands.The duchy revolted with the rest of the Netherlands against Philip II of Spain and joined the Union of Utrecht (1579). After the deposition of Philip II
column8: its sovereignty was vested in the States of Gelderland
column9: and the princes of Orange were stadtholders. In 1672
column10: the province was temporarily occupied by Louis XIV and
column12: the southeastern part including the ducal capital of Geldern fell to Prussia. Part of the Batavian Republic (1795–1806)
column13: of Louis Bonaparte’s Kingdom of Holland (1806–10)
column15: Gelderland became a province of the Kingdom of the Netherlands in 1815.During the Second World War
column16: it saw heavy fighting between Allied Paratroopers
column17: British XXX Corps and the German II SS Panzer Corps

column6: and the GelreDome in Arnhem. these venues offer concerts from popular artist. every year the municipality Renkum and Overbetuwe receive a large amount of tourist visiting because of the Battle of Arnhem. Often historical locations are visited

column1: Gelderland can roughly be divided into four geographical regions: the Veluwe in the north
column2: the Rivierenland including the Betuwe in the southwest
column3: the Achterhoek (literally meaning the "back corner") or Graafschap (which originally means earldom or county) in the east and the city-region of Arnhem and Nijmegen in the centre-south.

column1: These municipalities were merged with neighbouring ones:
Lichtenvoorde was merged into Groenlo (renamed Oost Gelre in 2006)
Millingen aan de Rijn and Ubbergen were merged into Groesbeek (renamed Berg en Dal in 2016)
Wehl was merged into DoetinchemThese municipalities were merged and given a new name:
Bergh and Didam have become Montferland
